This all builds on the excellent 2017 @AMRC report, "Facilitating adoption of off-patent, repurposed medicines into NHS clinical practice".  7/7

https://t.co/EZADhacVbd

It may be too challenging to collect sufficient evidence to licence the drug, particularly where the patient population for the new indication is very small (e.g. for gene
therapies) or is challenging for ethical or regulatory reasons (i.e. in children). 6/7 https://t.co/w6UlHoQEQt

A drug company may have sufficient evidence that a drug is clinically effective in a new indication or population, but there may be no commercial incentive to licence it â€“ for example where the drug is already low cost or generic. 5/7

Enabling access to an un-licenced or off-label drug may provide faster access to effective treatment ahead of planned licencing or where the cost of developing new medicine isn't financially viable, e.g. in rare diseases where patient numbers are small. #RareDiseaseDay2021 4/7 https://t.co/HDL4BQgbLB

Off-label prescribing can help innovation. Many valuable uses of medicines discovered this way. For example: aspirin is now used primarily for cardiac problems rather than as pain relief, and tricyclic antidepressants effective treatments for neuropathic pain relief. 3/7

This approach critical to our innovation agenda. Making the most of what we've got. Empowering "iteration". Using scientific disciplines and thoughtful regulation to empower, not impede, patient-safe discovery. 2/7

 @AACinnovation @MHRAgovuk @NICEComms @DHSCgovuk @NIHRresearch

8. We will strengthen public, patient and service user involvement in research. 

Thanks to @NIHRresearch  for progress on creating the highest standards of public, patient and service user involvement. ğŸ™

7.  Engage diverse populations in clinical research, to ensure research cohorts reflect the populations that will benefit from new treatments. 

Thanks to @BMEhealthEM for leading the way on diverse and underserved populations. ğŸ™

6.  Mobilise organisations and individuals to increase support for research. 

Thanks to @CQCpressoffice for looking at requirements for trusts and revalidation for doctors and nurses. ğŸ™

5. Improve the visibility of research across the health and care system. This means capturing referrals to research studies and follow-up activity as well as recruitment and recognising the value of everyday activities like good data collection in electronic health records.

4. align our research programmes and processes with the needs of the UK health and care system. This will also help industry and other researchers know what new products and evidence the system needs, supporting more rapid uptake into care once approved.

3. We aim to increase the use of innovative trial designs. Like the RELIEVE IBS-D study, which used new tech and a virtual trial design to enable rapid recruitment and safe participation from home. 

Thanks to @MHRAgovuk for their Innovative Licensing and Approvals Pathway. ğŸ™

2. We will launch a data enabled â€˜Find, recruit and follow-upâ€™ service increasing opportunities for people to be invited to participate in research. And enabling study sponsors to quickly find eligible participants and translate this into improved recruitment performance

4/4. We have to embrace digital tools and big data.  

We made millions of peopleâ€™s coronavirus test results available to the PRINCIPLE trial. Allowed trial team to identify possible participants â€“ and invite them to take part, with a really positive impact on recruitment.

3/4. We have to remain internationally competitive.

Through this pandemic, UK regulators got innovative trials off the ground in record time - a massive tribute to the MHRA, HRA and Research Ethics Committees. 

ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™

2/4. We have to embed research in the NHS.

We've launched 5 NIHR National Patient Recruitment Centres to make it quicker and easier for life science companies to deliver late-phase clinical researchâ€”at scale and at paceâ€”through the NHS.

1/4. We have to centre studies around patients.

At a single NIHR site in Newcastle where they used a virtual approach, recruitment was 67 percent faster, compared to 28 sites using a traditional approach!

7. Weight Management:  In July we launched an NHS 12-week weight loss app which has been downloaded more than 440,000 times.

https://t.co/J94dtIx0yI
6. Alcohol Calorie Labelling: We will consult shortly on our intention to make companies provide calorie labelling on all pre-packaged alcohol they sell. https://t.co/d29CZhgpWP

5. Out of Home Calorie Labelling: The obesity strategy confirmed we will introduce legislation to require large out-of-home sector businesses, with 250 or more employees, to calorie label the food they sell.  

https://t.co/mI7OvrbFfx

4. Traffic lights: The consultation on Front-of-Pack Nutrition Labelling closed on 21 October with just under 2700 responses. Helping people chose the right foods. A post-Brexit opportunity. 

https://t.co/OQuwu3chMy

3. Advertising: The obesity strategy confirmed we will introduce a 9pm watershed on TV for adverts for HFSS products. The 6 week consultation on a total HFSS advertising restriction online closed on 22 December.

https://t.co/Ky8FtMDUeV

2/2 Promotions: Our announcement on the 28th December 2020 confirmed we will legislate to stop the promotion of HFSS products by volume and prominent locations both online and in store in England.  

https://t.co/VhaIPw0uVt https://t.co/7Yz0ZUahmR

@Samfr We researched it heavily. The basic principle is that we need people to make a conscious decision to self-isolate, to take a test, and to trace their recent contacts. This requires them to trust the system. Lockdown showed trust is key. That's why we havent sought mandation.

@radioriley By the way, anyone who has symptoms can have a test. 

https://t.co/QJXmHxBXkj

@radioriley I agree. It's a pain in the proverbial. I wish tests would be conclusive. But in life, it is always very difficult to prove a negative. And an aspect of this virus, which is well documented, is that asymptomatic infectiousness is one of the most nasty spreaders of the disease.

If you have #coronavirus symptoms, you must get a test. If youâ€™re asked to isolate by NHS Test & Trace, then itâ€™s vital that you do.

https://t.co/QRjNXuPpzM

@brianpaddick @BBCr4today @MattHancock If you have #coronavirus symptoms, you must get a test. If youâ€™re asked to isolate by NHS Test & Trace, then itâ€™s vital that you do. These are straightforward principles. They are in everyone's interests. The alternative is lockdown. Scoring political points doesnt help.

@radioriley I should add that the huge, widespread commitment to the lockdown has demonstrated the public generally understand these points. And the alternative to isolate regime is that we keep lockdown protocols in place for longer.

@radioriley This is the learning of our surveys. It is very frustrating. It is not the fault of the government, it is just that the virus behaviours very challenging. That's why we need people to isolate for 14 days, to be sure they've got rid of asymptomatic infection.

@radioriley H Phil. (1) We are not forcing anyone. We rely on personal good will, self-interest and commitment to the common good. There are no fines. (2) This virus lurks asymptomatically in some people so that even the tests dont pick it up; and they can be infectious without symptoms.

@rowlsmanthorpe Hiya Rowland. Number of index cases today was 2,013, and thatâ€™s what tracers will work from tomorrow. Might be more asymptomatic new cases, but we work from people who test positive. The number of contacts per index case during lockdown is likely much lower than your estimates.
